Chaos

Chaos

The brief.

We had one week to design and build an interactive installation featuring both sound and visual as well as having an artistic orientation.

The team was composed of 4 interaction design students: Théo Monin, Noé Martineau, Enzo Wattebled & myself.

Concept

The idea of our project was to showcase the beauty behind mathematics and sciences. After some researches and brainstorming, we came out with different ideas such as working with fractals or recursion to generate shapes inspired by nature, working with systems and patterns to generate parametric patterns and sound and many more.

We wanted to put meaning into our project, so I came up with the idea to work from a book called the Chaos Theory from James Gleick. It depicts how researchers in the mid 19's discovered the chaotic nature of some physical phenomenon in physics and thermodynamics.

The goal we set for this project was to visualize the chaotic nature of some equations and use it to generate interesting visuals and sound.

Engineering first

Because the goal was not to build a static installation we quickly started to experiment with interactions. We wanted to allow the public to play with the equations and visualize a result impressively.

Because we had limited time and a lot of technical issues we've chosen an engineering fist approach, were we first experimented with the feasibility of our concept before diving into user experience and interaction design.

The controller

We built a simple controller made of a few different electronic components connected to a Picoboard electronic card and started to experiment with it.

After some testing, we improved it by using sliders to control the value of the equation parameters and a joystick to move the shape in 3D space.

Code

The visualization engine code was made with the Processing programming language ( a superset of java made for artists and designers ).

I started to build a debug mode was built in order to help us visualize the placement of our elements in a 3D world. Then most of the work was to generate the engine generating the attractor from the equations. Finally, I had to optimize the rendering process to allow it to run smoothly when the parameters changed.

We had to iterate a lot and fix many problems before ending up with a working prototype. Then we tested it within the team and refined it in an iterative way. Of course, there were many bugs but together we either fixed them or found ways to do otherwise.

In order to generate sound we user the PureData software, which consists of a nodal programming language. The two-way communication between PureData and Processing happen trough OSC communication.

The first test of the music generation algorithm showed that it looked too noise-like for most users. We composed ambient background music to add a bit more rhythm and coherence to the whole thing.

The word of the end

We had excellent feedback on this project and it was really interesting to test how users interact with it. Most of them tried themselves to play with sliders but we noticed that the joystick was used a few time then abandoned.

Virtual reality

Taking into account the feedback from the users I kept developing this project and built a VR prototype allowing the user to live a completely different experience. It allows the user to dive into the attractor and play with the parameters from the inside, the navigation was a lot more interesting than with the joystick.

Processing community days

Chaos was presented in the creative coding night during the processing community days. It was a nice moment to share about the project and get feedback from experienced designers and developers.
